block.p: FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''CURIOUS GEORGE,'' a musical starring the mischievous monkey; book and lyrics by Tom Toce and music by Timothy Brown. For children 5 and older. Theaterworks/USA, at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. Tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 P.M. Tickets: $18.50. Reservations: (212) 627-7373 or (212) 239-6200.
FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''CURIOUS GEORGE,'' a musical starring the mischievous monkey; book and lyrics by Tom Toce and music by Timothy Brown. For children 5 and older. Theaterworks/USA, at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. Tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 P.M. Tickets: $18.50. Reservations: (212) 627-7373 or (212) 239-6200.

''DON'T SEE MY BONES AND THINK I'M DEAD.'' A visit to an ancestral burial ground challenges urban youngsters to rediscover their roots, in a play written and performed by Urban Youth Theater, a company of teen-age actors, dancers and writers. Directed by Saundra McClain. At the Abrons Arts Center Experimental Theater, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7; Sunday at 3 P.M. Through Nov. 14. Tickets: $5. Information: (212) 598-0400.

''STORY SALAD 11,'' a theatrical adaptation mixing eight popular children's books including ''Amelia Bedelia,'' ''Clifford,'' ''Bravo'' and the ''Grouchy Neighbors,'' with songs, colorful costumes and props, dance and plenty of audience participation. At the Performing Arts Center, Kingsborough Community College, 2001 Oriental Boulevard, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, tomorrow at 2 P.M. Tickets: $8. Information: (718) 368-5596.

''TIKKI TIKKI TEMBO'' AND ''ST. GEORGE AND THE DRAGON.'' Two children's musicals, the former a Chinese fable about a little boy with a long name, the latter a legend complete with dragon, damsel in distress and brave knight, are collaborations by the Bronx Arts Ensemble and the Belmont Italian-American Playhouse. They will be presented on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Riverdale Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 5625 Arlington Avenue, at West 256th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx. Tickets: $7. Information: (718) 601-7399.
Events

''CREATURE COMFORTS.'' How are animals preparing for the winter? Discover which animals are leaving for warmer places, storing food or just sleeping until spring during a stroll through Central Park's Ramble with the educator Debbie Dubitsky, tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 P.M. Meet at Belvedere Castle, midpark at 79th Street, Manhattan. Afterward, build a feeder for the nonmigrating birds. Free. Registration: (212) 772-0210.

''DANCES BY VERY YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS.'' Dances for children created by children. Adventurous choreographers from age 6 to 16 explore dance with the Dance Theater Workshop resident dance educator, Ellen Robbins, in a program of short works presented tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M., at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $12; $8 for children under 12. Reservations are recommended: (212) 924-0077.

''THE DOCTOR IS IN,'' tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the Staten Island Children's Museum, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. A veterinarian will answer all pet questions. For children of all ages. Free with admission. Also tomorrow and Sunday (and next Saturday and Sunday), a ''Cat Collage'' workshop from 1 to 4:30 P.M. Children will snip fuzzy faces of domestic and wild cats from photographs to create a feline collage. Fee: $2 in addition to museum admission. Admission: $4; children under 2, free. Information: (718) 273-2060.

EASTERN EUROPEAN JEWISH FOLK TALES. The Eldridge Street Synagogue, a turn-of-the century National Historic Landmark at 12 Eldridge Street, Lower East Side, will be the backdrop for an afternoon of Jewish folk tales on Sunday at 1 P.M. Vered Hankin will tell stories in the inspirational setting, and the audience will be encouraged to participate. Admission: $10; $6 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 978-8800.

''FROM TAIKO TO TUMBLING.'' The sounds of Japan's taiko drums will fill the air in the opening concert of the ''Just Kidding!'' series, tomorrow at 11 A.M. at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. Taikoza, a five-member ensemble, will perform on traditional Japanese instruments, and the Tung Ching Chinese Center for the Arts will present an excerpt from ''Princess Iron Fan,'' a tale about the Monkey Sun and his enemy, Princess Iron Fan, in a one-hour program for children 5 and older. Tickets: $6. Information: (212) 864-5400. After the performance, the Children's Museum of Manhattan, 212 West 83d Street, will have related programs at 1:30 and 3 P.M. The ''Just Kidding!'' ticket stub can be presented for a $3 admission. Information: (212) 721-1234.

''GROWING UP WITH OPERA,'' a family series presented by the Metropolitan Opera Guild to introduce children ages 4 to 6 to the musical art form by demonstrating that opera is really a story that is sung. Audience members are invited to add their two cents to the action on stage and then discuss the results at the end of the performance. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1 and 3 P.M. at Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village. Tickets: $10. Information: (212) 769-7008.

MARK COOPER'S MUSICAL MOBILES. Children can join the artist Mark Cooper in creating mobiles tomorrow from noon to 5 P.M. at the Children's Museum of the Arts, 182 Lafayette Street, SoHo. Free with museum admission: $5. Information: (212) 941-9198.

''MOTHERS AND OTHERS FAMILY FEST!'' The annual harvest festival and fund-raiser will take place on Sunday from 2 to 5 P.M. at Chelsea Piers Sports Complex, Pier 62, at 23d Street at the Hudson River, Manhattan. There will be plenty of activities for children, including storytelling, a scavenger hunt, face painting and gourd monster making. Teen-agers will have access to in-line skating, wall climbing, basketball, soccer and gymnastics. Tickets: $250 for a family of 4; $90 per person; $45 per child. Information: (212) 242-0010, extension 320.

''SATURDAYS ALIVE!,'' at the Arts Connection, 120 West 46th Street, Manhattan. ''Muppets Make Puppets,'' a workshop with artists from the Jim Henson Foundation, from 12:30 to 2:30 P.M. ''Out of Your Seat and On Your Feet,'' a workshop with artists from Freestyle Repertory Theater, also at 12:30 P.M. Tickets for the workshops: $2. ''The Gizmo Guys,'' a performance by the juggling, joking duo, at 3 P.M. Tickets: $6. Information: (212) 302-7433, extension 1440.

''STORYTELLING IN THE GALLERIES: TRANSFORMATIONS.'' Joe Cross and Donna Couteau will present stories and songs from Ojibwa and Kwakiutl American Indian traditions that explore the wonders of creation and nature's transformation, tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Hall of the Americas, first floor, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Admission: $4; students, $2; the elderly, $1.50. Information: (718) 638-5000, extension 327.

''SILLY BILLY,'' a zany magician who encourages children from the audience to get into his act, will bring his magic show and fractured fairy tales to Caroline's Kids Klub, 1626 Broadway, at 49th Street, tomorrow and Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets: $12. Reservations necessary. For youngsters ages 3 to 9. Reservations: (212) 757-4100.

''WATERMELON PATCH,'' an imaginative trip through songs and adaptations of world folk tales by the storyteller-singer-songwriter Bill Gordh. The title song is about a search for the world's biggest watermelon. Tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. at the West End Children's Theater, 2911 Broadway, at 113th Street, Morningside Heights. Tickets: $10. Information: (212) 877-6115.

''WEST INDIAN MUSIC, SONG AND DANCE,'' Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Donnell Library Center's Central Children's Room, 20 West 53d Street, Manhattan. There will be music and audience participation, including a Limbo Line, for children 5 and older. Information: (212) 621-0618.
Exhibitions

''BEAKMAN'S WORLD ON TOUR.'' The wacky science wizard is taking his world to the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, through Jan. 3. Visitors can take a journey into the Philippine rain forest, find out what they weigh on the moon, perform hands-on experiments, meet talking penguins and discover Mt. Beakmore in the 4,000-square-foot traveling exhibition based on the ''Beakman's World'' television series. Museum hours: Mondays through Wednesdays, 9:30 A.M. to 2 P.M.; Thursdays through Sundays, 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $6; $4 for children 4 to 15 and the elderly. Information: (718) 699-0005.

''WORLD CIRCUS,'' a 1,200-square-foot exhibition at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Place, Crown Heights, on view through Jan. 3, focuses on the circuses of various cultures. It is more like a road show than a static museum display. Learn clowning, juggling and stilt-walking in a circus workshop every Saturday and Sunday in November at 1 P.M., beginning this weekend. Also tomorrow, at 11:30 A.M., a clown workshop for toddlers. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 2 to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Events are free with suggested admission: $3. Information: (718) 735-4402.
Zoos

STATEN ISLAND ZOO, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton. Want to adopt an adorable hedgehog or a fascinating boa constrictor? Think again. A workshop tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. will reveal why these may not make great pets. Free with zoo admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Free on Wednesdays after 2 P.M. Information: (718) 442-3101.
